OTTAWA — Quebec MP Maxime Bernier submitted the paperwork to make his new political party official Wednesday but does not have to identify the donors of more than $350,000 he raised in the last seven weeks. Bernier clutched a thick brown folder under his arm as he arrived at Elections Canada offices in Gatineau, Que., to seek official registration for the People's Party of Canada. Quebec's election result was bad for Trudeau, good for almost everyone else  CBC News

François ​Legault hadn't even delivered his victory speech after Monday's Quebec election when he received a congratulatory phone call from Ottawa. It was federal Conservative Leader Andrew Scheer on the line — and he wanted to be the first. ​Legault's Coalition Avenir Quebec party doesn't have formal ties to Scheer's party. Conservatives still might have the most to gain from Legault's triumph. Both parties support lower taxes. Quebec election: CAQ tries to crack western Quebec in final push  CBC News

As the final campaign push began this weekend, the Coalition Avenir Québec candidates in the five ridings of West Quebec held a news conference in Gatineau with a message for anyone who wants change in the region. "You have a unique chance on Monday to end 40 years of Liberal reign here in the Outaouais," said the CAQ candidate in the Papineau riding, Mathieu Lacombe. "The Liberal MNAs in West Quebec, we have to say, have betrayed the region for too long," Lacombe said, suggesting the region's voters would be better served with CAQ MNAs in a CAQ government. item.title: Philippe Couillard steps down, making way for a 'new generation' of Liberals - CBC News
item.description:
Philippe Couillard steps down, making way for a 'new generation' of Liberals  CBC News

Philippe Couillard is leaving politics, he announced Thursday, closing the book on nearly 15 uninterrupted years of Liberal governments in Quebec. With his wife Suzanne Pilote, by his side, Couillard stood at a podium in the lobby of Quebec's parliament building and told reporters he is leaving the province in a much better state than it was in when he came to power. But he said after putting all his energy into public service, staying in politics, in any role, would be "more than I feel I am humanly capable of." item.title: François Legault would invoke notwithstanding clause to ban hijabs from civil service - CBC News
item.description:
François Legault would invoke notwithstanding clause to ban hijabs from civil service  CBC News

Quebec's premier-designate says he is prepared to invoke the notwithstanding clause to enforce a prohibition on any public employee from wearing a religious symbol in the workplace. François Legault would also move swiftly to reduce the number of immigrants allowed into the province by 20 per cent. He made the comments Tuesday, at his first news conference since his Coalition Avenir Québec won a decisive majority in Monday's provincial election, beating out the incumbent Liberals.
